conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area on a surface.
The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface.
In the first image, shadows A, B, C, and D are cast by four objects, with the light source positioned such that each shadow is relatively close to its respective object.
As the light source moves backward, shadows tend to become larger because the angle of light hitting the objects becomes more acute, causing the shadows to stretch.
As the light source moves backward, the shadows will move further away from the objects in the direction opposite to the light source.
Shadow A becomes larger and shifts further away from the object as the light source moves backward.
Shadow B enlarges and moves away from the object as the light source retreats.
Shadow C becomes even larger and more stretched out, moving further from the object as the light source moves backward.
Shadow D becomes larger and shifts away from the object as the light source moves backward.
In the second image, all shadows (A, B, C, and D) have increased in size and shifted position, moving further away from their respective objects.
When the light source moves backward above the objects, shadows A, B, C, and D become larger and shift further away from the objects in the direction opposite to the light source.
